text: Yeah, it feels pretty bad/anti-climactic.
Yeah whenever triumph takes a game it always seems kinda meh at the table.
It's starting to reach LabMan-level of meh in my view.
I agree. Lab man wins are equally meh. Once you see it happen a couple of times you don't care to see it happen again.

I am a man of opinions, as anyone who interacts with me for a time learns, but they're just that - mine. That's the beauty of Magic, and especially EDH, you can build and do what you want that fits your persona. The arguments over what's 'good' or 'bad' adds so much spice to the conversation. :wink:

Yeah I'm fairly similar in that regard. I have to agree that as long as a player is having fun then there's really little harm to them doing anything that isn't cheating in order to win. The perception of good vs. bad magic shifts from player to player and that variance is what makes the game cool to begin with. You don't have to think Jolrael is good in order for me to be able to use her effectively. If I do use her effectively against yiu then you get to look at that card and your evaluation of it through a new lens.
But you should fully expect Henry to deride you if you ever win with Lab Man in his presence.
Of course!
Oh I'll do it whether you're there or not.
Lol
My brother's all argue about sports teams, I argue against tired combos.
Well that's just part of being the angry old man on the porch of Magic.
I need younguns to yell at, in my case it's narrow deck building.
I see a lot more tired labman-type combos from oldsters than from kids
I'm guilty. I've got Doomsday Kess planned...

text: its such a hated theme, but it's totally viable. I think most of the time people don't have efficient enough win conditions in those decks, and this makes games slow and unfun. If we could get a commander that had something along the lines of "During each players upkeep deal X damage to them, where X is equal to the number of lands in their graveyard."
then we might see some good land deso decks
So your view is take a hated archetype and push people to make more of that
The problem with land destruction is so many people are terrible at it. It's the country music of magic. Yeah, okay, Johnny Cash existed, but 99.9% of it is Jason Aldeen.

I've never minded an Avacyn, Angel of Hope deck dropping an Armageddon. You just scoop and play again. It's no different than a well-timed Overrun. The game just ends. That's not what happens though. It's some doucheknuckle just dragging the game out or hate-dropping one as he's about to loose.

How many games have you been in where everything was destroyed turn after turn or statis is in perma effect. People don't enjoy having to play a game that they aren't actually playing. Adding in a fast win condition would help

I can't say that's a problem too often, and and I don't know if encouraging people to be more bad at the thing they're already bad at really fixes it. I'm not sure damage per lands in the yard really does it, either. You can easily turn it off with any number of grave hate cards that people should already be running and all you achieve then is a radically slower game against a deck built around destroying lands whose win-con got toasted by a Bojuka Bog or  new Taigam
All that said, it's probably not gonna happen. WotC doesn't seem to want mld as an archetype.
Regardless of whether we like it or don't.
True. Maybe something to with a does trigger. Make it a little more fun for commander by adding a non damage effect to it. Each opponent draws 5 cards when a land controlled by them dies.
Best we could see is maybe a Ghost Quarter-type commander
Where you need to run them out of lands first before they start staying perma-gone
That could be interesting and follows wizards love of nonbasic hate in commander
It would have to scaleable to make it worth while. Activated ability without tapping or tap ability without mana cost

Enchantment

text: Make your opponents play Wall-tribal.
In a touch over a 1000 decks, apparently. Had no idea. Something about turning critter into walls is just...satisfying

Wut...
That's almost as great as darksteel mutation.

Really shits on those Thrun players.
Well, problem is when Thrun hits he's usually pretty suited up so one may be all that matters

I'm curious about Aurification's leave the battlefield trigger...if you stifle that, and the gold counters stay, are those creatures still walls, or does Aurification itself define the effect of those counters?
I'd guess they don't do anyting without the enchantment around?
I think the divinity counters no longer grant indestructible once Kindred Boon is gone right?
Yes, that's correct. That's why I dislike Gwafa Hazid, too. Counters only matter when he's in play.

<@U3L7A68JC> they're not walls anymore if Aurification leaves the battlefield, stifled leave-the-battlefield trigger or not. Same thing as Gwafa and Kindred Boon. It's because the Aurification has the ability itself. Look at [[Mathas]] for comparison.
